article: I was born disabled.A difficult birth, feet first, my head  _  .  _  I was 3, the Hospital in Boston told my father I had cerebral palsy .A loss of oxygen to my brain had destroyed brain  _  to the right side of my body.But  _  son of my dad's was going to be disabled.Every day my dad  _  me on the bedroom floor to  _  my right leg.His job was to craft them straight, at any  _  .Back and forth, up and down, my dad pushed and pulled the muscles into  _  .But my dad's help didn't stop there.  _  my 13 birthday, he threw me a special party.When everybody was gone, he brought me a set of boxing gloves.We put them on.My dad continued to  _  me mercilessly.Each time I  _  him to stop.He told me I was a man now and things would be extra  _  for me.That same year, I was the only kid in my neighborhood that wasn't  _  for Little League.Everybody laughed at me.Two weeks  _  , Dad started the Shed Park Minor League.Dad coached the Yankees and  _  me a pitcher .In high school, I became a football star.The  _  of my dad's love guaranteed I walked and more.In 1997, a brain doctor in San Jose told me I didn't have cerebral palsy  after all  . My dad never knew the whole truth  since  he passed away years ago.But all that  _  is the bottom line.After all his  _  , on this Father's Day, like every Father's Day, I'm no longer disabled.
